Framework

The AI Tools Assessment Framework for Marketing Leaders

Why structured assessment beats ad-hoc adoption ‚Äî and how to build a unified AI strategy for your team.

üìÖ February 2026 ‚è±Ô∏è 8 min read ‚úçÔ∏è Christopher O'Hara

The reality: Most marketing teams have already adopted AI tools ‚Äî but in a fragmented, bottom-up way. Individual contributors are paying for ChatGPT Plus out of pocket. Teams have their own spreadsheets of "approved" tools. Nobody knows what's actually being used, what's working, or where the gaps are. This framework changes that.

The Problem with Ad-Hoc AI Adoption

Walk into any product marketing organization today and you'll find the same pattern: a patchwork of AI tools adopted through individual initiative rather than strategic planning.

This organic adoption isn't inherently bad ‚Äî it shows your team is resourceful and motivated. But it creates real problems:

  • Shadow AI: Tools being used without IT/security awareness, creating compliance and data privacy risks
  • Redundant spending: Multiple teams paying for overlapping capabilities
  • Knowledge silos: Best practices trapped in individual workflows
  • Skill gaps: Uneven adoption leaving some team members behind
  • Missed opportunities: Enterprise tools (like SAP Joule or Microsoft Copilot) sitting unused while teams pay for consumer alternatives

The solution isn't to crack down on bottom-up adoption. It's to understand what's already happening and build a strategy around it.

The Six Dimensions of AI Readiness

Our assessment framework evaluates AI adoption across six dimensions ‚Äî each revealing different aspects of your team's readiness and needs:

01
Current Tool Inventory

What's already being used? Map both sanctioned enterprise tools and personal/team-adopted solutions.

02
Usage Patterns

How frequently and for what tasks? Understanding actual workflows reveals where AI adds value.

03
Pain Points & Blockers

What's preventing effective adoption? Training, access, quality, integration, or compliance concerns?

04
Capability Gaps

What do people wish AI could do that current tools don't support? This reveals unmet demand.

05
Budget Reality

Who's paying for what? Out-of-pocket spending signals unmet enterprise needs.

06
Skill Distribution

Where are your power users? Where are the beginners? This informs training priorities.

Assessment Methodology

The framework uses a structured survey approach that balances depth with completion rates. Key design principles:

üéØ Segment by Team & Role Level

AI needs vary dramatically between individual contributors and directors, between pricing analysts and content marketers. Capture this context upfront so you can analyze patterns by segment.

üìä Distinguish Enterprise vs. Shadow Tools

Separate questions for company-provided tools (Joule, Copilot, etc.) versus personally-adopted tools (ChatGPT, Claude, Perplexity). This reveals the gap between official strategy and ground-truth usage.

üîç Map Tasks, Not Just Tools

Asking "what tools do you use?" only tells half the story. Asking "what tasks do you use AI for?" reveals where AI is actually creating value ‚Äî and where opportunities exist.

üí° Capture the Wish List

The most valuable data often comes from what people want AI to do but can't today. This forward-looking data shapes your roadmap.

üö´ Surface Blockers Explicitly

Don't assume you know why adoption is lagging. Ask directly: is it awareness, access, training, quality, privacy concerns, or workflow integration?

Key Questions to Ask

Tool Inventory

  • Which enterprise AI tools are you currently using? (multi-select)
  • Which third-party tools are you using for work, even if not officially sanctioned?
  • Are there tools you've tried and abandoned? Why?

Usage & Tasks

  • How frequently do you use AI tools for work? (scale: never ‚Üí multiple times daily)
  • What tasks do you use AI for? (e.g., writing, research, presentations, data analysis)
  • What are your top 3 most time-consuming tasks?

Pain Points

  • Rate your satisfaction with current AI tools (1-5)
  • What's blocking you from using AI more effectively? (multi-select blockers)
  • What AI capabilities would be most valuable to you? (wish list)

Budget & Readiness

  • Are you or your team paying for AI tools out of pocket?
  • How would you rate your AI skill level? (1-5)
  • Would you attend AI training sessions?

From Assessment to Action

Raw survey data is just the starting point. The real value comes from analysis and action planning:

1. Identify Your Tool Stack Gaps

Compare enterprise tools available versus tools actually being used. Large gaps signal adoption problems ‚Äî either awareness, training, or capability mismatches.

2. Quantify Shadow AI Spend

If 60% of your team is paying $20/month for ChatGPT Plus, that's budget that could fund enterprise licenses with better security and collaboration features.

3. Prioritize by Pain Point Frequency

If "lack of training" is the #1 blocker across teams, invest in enablement before buying more tools. If "quality concerns" dominate, evaluate different models or fine-tuning.

4. Build Your Capability Roadmap

Aggregate wish list data to identify the 3-5 capabilities with highest demand. These become your pilot projects.

5. Segment Your Training Approach

Skill distribution data tells you where to focus: beginners need fundamentals, power users need advanced workflows and prompt engineering.

üí° Pro Tip: Run Assessments Quarterly

AI capabilities and adoption patterns change fast. A one-time assessment gives you a snapshot; quarterly pulses let you track progress and catch emerging needs early.

Real-World Application

We built this framework to assess AI readiness within SAP's BDC Data & Analytics organization ‚Äî a 100+ person product marketing team spanning competitive intelligence, pricing, field enablement, and AI strategy.

The assessment revealed several insights that shaped our 2026 strategy:

  • Enterprise tool underutilization: Less than 20% of the team had tried SAP Joule despite universal access
  • Significant shadow spend: Over 40% paying for personal ChatGPT/Claude subscriptions
  • Training as top blocker: "Don't know what tools are available" ranked #1
  • Clear capability demand: Competitive intelligence automation and content repurposing topped the wish list

These findings directly informed budget allocation, training priorities, and our pilot project selection.

Conclusion: Strategy Before Tools

The temptation in AI adoption is to start with tools: "Let's get everyone access to Copilot" or "We should evaluate these five vendors." But tools without strategy leads to the fragmented landscape most organizations already have.

Start instead with assessment. Understand what's actually happening on the ground. Map the gaps between current state and desired capabilities. Then ‚Äî and only then ‚Äî build your tooling strategy on a foundation of real data.

The organizations that win the AI productivity race won't be the ones that adopted the most tools first. They'll be the ones that adopted the right tools, with the right training, for the right use cases.

Structured assessment is how you get there.

Christopher O'Hara is VP of Product Marketing at SAP, where he leads AI and next-generation marketing strategy. He's the author of "Customer Data Platforms" (Wiley) and writes about the future of product marketing at futureofpmm.com.
